paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Whether intratumoral mRNA vaccination can induce an interferon-rich tumor state that improves responsiveness to anti-PD-L1 immune checkpoint therapy.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse efficacy cohort (combination therapy)
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Pooled repeat-experiment mouse cohort used to evaluate antitumor efficacy of intratumoral mRNA vaccine plus anti-PD-L1 treatment.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse matched control cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Matched controls including vaccine-only, ICI-only, and vehicle conditions used to benchmark combination effects in murine models.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human retrospective metastatic cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Retrospective translational cohort of metastatic patients treated with ICI, stratified by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human vaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subset of retrospective metastatic patients with prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination before or around ICI treatment window.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human unvaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Comparator subset of retrospective metastatic patients without prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination in the analyzed cohort.

major_limitations: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized, so residual confounding is likely.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients, complicating interpretation.
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.
